title: Chinese Government provides $19.5 million USD grant for Phase II of Khartoum State Electricity Facilities Rehabilitation Project (Linked to #47128, #57982)
description: In October 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sudan signed a $19.5 million USD grant agreement for Phase II of the Khartoum State Electricity Facilities Rehabilitation Project. China National Electric Engineering Co., Ltd. (CNEEC or 中国电力工程有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project was completed, but the precise project start and end dates are unknown.  In 2002, China provided two loans for Phase I of this project (see #47128, #57982).
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Phase 2 of the National Capital Power Project and Phase 2 of the Khartoum State Electricity Project.  The Chinese project title is 苏丹首都电网改造工程.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $19.5 million USD grant for Phase II of Khartoum State Electricity Facilities Rehabilitation Project (Linked to #47128, #57982)

# Description
In October 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sudan signed a $19.5 million USD grant agreement for Phase II of the Khartoum State Electricity Facilities Rehabilitation Project. China National Electric Engineering Co., Ltd. (CNEEC or 中国电力工程有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project was completed, but the precise project start and end dates are unknown.  In 2002, China provided two loans for Phase I of this project (see #47128, #57982).
justification: Electricity facilities rehabilitation project likely focused on grid infrastructure improvements, with potential impacts on both renewable and non-renewable energy systems
evidence: Electricity facilities rehabilitation, part of multi-phase project, no specific energy source mentioned

title: Chinese government loans USD 18.1 million to Sudan for Rehabilitation of the Electricity Project of the National Capital
description: In 2006, the Chinese government loaned USD 18.1 million to Sudan for a project titled "Rehabilitation of the Electricity Project of the National Capital" , as reported in the Bank of Sudan's 2006 annual report. The precise terms of this loan and which Chinese government bureau provided it are uncertain. In 2007, $132.7 million USD was drawn down for "Rehabilitation of the Electricity Project of the National Capital" and other projects, although it is unclear what the breakdown between projects are.
staff_comments: This project may be related to the Khartoum State Electricity Facilities Rehabilitation Project (captured in #47128, #47205).
combined_text:

# Title
Chinese government loans USD 18.1 million to Sudan for Rehabilitation of the Electricity Project of the National Capital

# Description
In 2006, the Chinese government loaned USD 18.1 million to Sudan for a project titled "Rehabilitation of the Electricity Project of the National Capital" , as reported in the Bank of Sudan's 2006 annual report. The precise terms of this loan and which Chinese government bureau provided it are uncertain. In 2007, $132.7 million USD was drawn down for "Rehabilitation of the Electricity Project of the National Capital" and other projects, although it is unclear what the breakdown between projects are.
justification: Electricity rehabilitation project likely involves grid infrastructure improvements, but specific details on energy sources are unclear
evidence: Rehabilitation of electricity project, national capital focus, lack of specific energy source details

title: Chinese Government provides loan for Third Circuit Er Roseires-Khartoum Electricity Transmission Project (Linked to Project ID#67168)
description: In 2006, the Chinese Government provided a loan to Government of Sudan for the Third Circuit Er Roseires-Khartoum Electricity Transmission Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance an RMB 740 million commercial contract that it signed with Shanghai Electric Power Transmission and Distribution Group (上海电气输配电工程成套有限公司) in 2006.   The project involved the construction of a third circuit (a double-circuit 220 kV power transmission line) from Er Roseires (a town in eastern Sudan 60 km from the border with Ethiopia) to the country’s capital (Khartoum) via Renk and Rabak. It also supported 9 substations along the route of the transmission line: (1) Jabel Aulia substation (贾贝尔·罗里亚变电站)；(2) Mashkour substation (马士科变电站); (3) Rabak substation (罗巴克变电站)；(4) Rank substation (兰克变电站)；(5) Roseires substation (罗塞瑞斯变电站)；(6) Freezone substation (保税区)；(7) Rwaba substation (瑞瓦巴变电站)；(8) Ten Delty substation (坦德体变电站)；and (9) Obaid (Obeid) substation (欧信德变电站).  Shanghai Electric Power Transmission and Distribution Group  was the contractor responsible project project implementation. Construction began in 2007. The 'first' substation was put into operation in August 2007. At that time, the 'second' substation had reached the equipment installation stage, and construction of the 'third' substation had began. The project was ultimately completed in July 2009.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Third Circuit Roseires-Khartoum Project, the Rabak-Obied Third Circuit Elroseires-Khartoum Electricity Project, and the Sudan EPC Project of 9 Substations of 220kv. The Chinese project title is 苏丹9座220kV变电站工程总承包项目 or 的苏丹220KV变电站总承包项目. The Arabic project title is  الروصيرص - خرطوم.2.   Er Roseires is sometimes referred to as Rosairess or Elroseres.3. In 2004, CMEC Comtrans International Co., Ltd. signed an implementation contract with Sudan's National Electricity Corporation (NEC) for the Third Circuit Er Roseires-Khartoum Electricity Transmission Project.  It is unclear if the proceeds of the loan were also used to support this contract. This issue warrants further investigation.4. The precise face value of the loan is unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes that the loan in question was an export buyer's credit and that it was used to finance 85% of the total cost of the RMB 740 million commercial contract. This issue warrants further investigation. 5. Some sources suggest that the commercial contract value was $83.33 million rather than RMB 740 million.6. The project was divided into two phases. The first phase  (with a commercial contract value of RMB 415 million)  supported 5 substations and the second phase (with a commercial contract value of $43 million) supported 4 substations.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides loan for Third Circuit Er Roseires-Khartoum Electricity Transmission Project (Linked to Project ID#67168)

# Description
In 2006, the Chinese Government provided a loan to Government of Sudan for the Third Circuit Er Roseires-Khartoum Electricity Transmission Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance an RMB 740 million commercial contract that it signed with Shanghai Electric Power Transmission and Distribution Group (上海电气输配电工程成套有限公司) in 2006.   The project involved the construction of a third circuit (a double-circuit 220 kV power transmission line) from Er Roseires (a town in eastern Sudan 60 km from the border with Ethiopia) to the country’s capital (Khartoum) via Renk and Rabak. It also supported 9 substations along the route of the transmission line: (1) Jabel Aulia substation (贾贝尔·罗里亚变电站)；(2) Mashkour substation (马士科变电站); (3) Rabak substation (罗巴克变电站)；(4) Rank substation (兰克变电站)；(5) Roseires substation (罗塞瑞斯变电站)；(6) Freezone substation (保税区)；(7) Rwaba substation (瑞瓦巴变电站)；(8) Ten Delty substation (坦德体变电站)；and (9) Obaid (Obeid) substation (欧信德变电站).  Shanghai Electric Power Transmission and Distribution Group  was the contractor responsible project project implementation. Construction began in 2007. The 'first' substation was put into operation in August 2007. At that time, the 'second' substation had reached the equipment installation stage, and construction of the 'third' substation had began. The project was ultimately completed in July 2009.
justification: Project focuses on electricity transmission infrastructure, which is essential for energy distribution but does not directly contribute to renewable energy generation
evidence: Construction of 220 kV power transmission line and 9 substations, no mention of renewable energy sources

title: Chinese Embassy in Sudan donates office equipment to Sudan Ministry of International Cooperation
description: On July 20, 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Sudan held a ceremony to hand over a set of office equipment to the Sudan Ministry of International Cooperation (中国驻苏丹使馆向国际合作部赠送办公设备). More than 10 officials including Fatah, Minister of the Ministry, and Thaher, Director of the Department of Bilateral Cooperation attended the signing ceremony. Zhang Dong, Chinese Ambassador to Sudan, and Hao Hongshe, Business Counselor, were invited to attend. Deputy Minister Fatah and Ambassador Zhang Dong signed the handover certificate respectively.  The value of the equipment is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Sudan donates office equipment to Sudan Ministry of International Cooperation

# Description
On July 20, 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Sudan held a ceremony to hand over a set of office equipment to the Sudan Ministry of International Cooperation (中国驻苏丹使馆向国际合作部赠送办公设备). More than 10 officials including Fatah, Minister of the Ministry, and Thaher, Director of the Department of Bilateral Cooperation attended the signing ceremony. Zhang Dong, Chinese Ambassador to Sudan, and Hao Hongshe, Business Counselor, were invited to attend. Deputy Minister Fatah and Ambassador Zhang Dong signed the handover certificate respectively.  The value of the equipment is unknown.
justification: Donation of office equipment to government ministry is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Office equipment donation to Ministry of International Cooperation, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China offers up to 60 Chinese Government Scholarships to Sudanese students between 2006 and 2008
description: On 24 June 2006, representatives of the Chinese Government and Government of Sudan signed the 2006-2008 Implementation Plan for the Cultural Cooperation Agreement. According to Section 4, Article 17 of this plan, China committed to offering up to 30 Chinese Government Scholarships per year to Sudanese young people for studying in China. The value of each scholarship is unknown.
combined_text:

EDUCATION

# Title
China offers up to 60 Chinese Government Scholarships to Sudanese students between 2006 and 2008

# Description
On 24 June 2006, representatives of the Chinese Government and Government of Sudan signed the 2006-2008 Implementation Plan for the Cultural Cooperation Agreement. According to Section 4, Article 17 of this plan, China committed to offering up to 30 Chinese Government Scholarships per year to Sudanese young people for studying in China. The value of each scholarship is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on educational scholarships without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Chinese Government Scholarships for Sudanese students, education sector focus

title: CHEC provides loan — via deferred payment arrangement — for Extension and Dredging Works of Berths 17 and 18 at Port Sudan Project
description: On or around June 8, 2006, Sea Ports Corporation (SPC) — a Sudanese state-owned company — and China Harbour Engineering Co. Ltd (CHEC) signed a deferred payment ("延期付款”) agreement for the Extension and Dredging Works of Berths 17 and 18 at Port Sudan Project. The loan carried an 8-year maturity and the borrower (SPC) was expected to make monthly repayments with the retained (ring-fenced) portion of its monthly operating income. The other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, is is known that SPC used the deferred payment arrangement to finance a $110 million commercial (EPC) contract that it signed with China Harbour Engineering Co. Ltd on June 8, 2006.  The purpose of the project was to construct two 70,000-ton (TEU) container terminals at Port Sudan (Berths 17 and 18). The total length of the terminals is 781 meters with a water depth of 16 meters. The project scope also included dredging activities (for a foundation trench, turning basin, main channel) with a total volume of 3.5 million cubic meters. CHEC was the contractor responsible for implementation.  Project implementation commenced in January 2007. The project was originally expected to reach completion within 30 months (July 2009). As of December 2009, construction of the main terminals and ancillary works were complete, but site cleaning activities had not yet been undertaken. The project was ultimately completed in February 2011. An official project completion ceremony was held on December 21, 2011.  However, the deferred payment (lending) arrangement between SPC and CHEC appears to have underperformed vis-à-vis the original expectations of CHEC. Sudan’s Ministry of Finance initially set up a special bank account into which SPC deposited its monthly operating income (worth approximately $200 million a year), and SPC was allowed to retain some but not all of these funds for its own purposes (such as construction and maintenance of port facilities and servicing its debts to CHEC). However, Sudan’s Ministry of Finance subsequently took away SPC’s ability to retain a portion of its monthly income around 2011 (when the Sudanese Government faced an acute foreign exchange shortage), which made it substantially more difficult for SPC to honor its monthly repayment obligations. CHEC later disclosed that SPC was in arrears but continued to make interest payments.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Port Sudan New Container Terminal and Dredging Project. The Chinese project title is 17-18號泊位延長段及疏浚工程 or 苏丹港17/18号码头.2. In a typical receivables financing agreement (or deferred payment agreement), the company that the project owner in the host country has selected as its engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor is also a lender to the project owner. The company assigns receivables under its EPC contract with the project owner to one of or more banks. Upon assignment of receivables, the bank or banks will release funds to the company so it can discharge its obligations under the receivables financing agreement  as a lender. Receivables financing is also known as accounts receivable financing (finance) or A/R financing (finance) or 应收账款融资 (in Chinese). These other terms are used because the accounts receivable of a company (i.e., unpaid invoices) are being used as collateral to unlock working capital—typically in the form of a bank loan (‘receivables loan’). Sellers often face cash flow problems when their buyers do not make full payment at the due date of the invoice. A receivables financing arrangement addresses this problem by allowing them to sell their outstanding invoices to a bank at a discounted rate. This approach allows the seller to receive the remaining invoice amount before the due date of the invoice. The bank either gets its money back at invoice maturity through the seller (acting as a collecting agent) or directly from the debtor.3. In Chinese, a deferred payment agreement is known as《延期付款协议》.4. The face value of the deferred payment agreement is unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes that it is equivalent to 85% of the value of the EPC contract ($110 million). 5. SPC Contact: Mr. Jalal Eldin. M.A. Shelia (General Manager) Tel: +249912308514 Email: spcp@sudanmail.net; Spcp21@sudanports.gov.sd; spc_dmea@yahoo.com.6. Sea Ports Corporation (SPC) is an independent state corporation of Sudan that governs, constructs and maintains the ports, harbors and lighthouses of Sudan. The company was founded in 1974 by the government of Sudan to be the national port operator and port authority.7. This loan is omitted from the SAIS-CARI database of Chinese loan commitments that was released in July 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
CHEC provides loan — via deferred payment arrangement — for Extension and Dredging Works of Berths 17 and 18 at Port Sudan Project

# Description
On or around June 8, 2006, Sea Ports Corporation (SPC) — a Sudanese state-owned company — and China Harbour Engineering Co. Ltd (CHEC) signed a deferred payment ("延期付款”) agreement for the Extension and Dredging Works of Berths 17 and 18 at Port Sudan Project. The loan carried an 8-year maturity and the borrower (SPC) was expected to make monthly repayments with the retained (ring-fenced) portion of its monthly operating income. The other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, is is known that SPC used the deferred payment arrangement to finance a $110 million commercial (EPC) contract that it signed with China Harbour Engineering Co. Ltd on June 8, 2006.  The purpose of the project was to construct two 70,000-ton (TEU) container terminals at Port Sudan (Berths 17 and 18). The total length of the terminals is 781 meters with a water depth of 16 meters. The project scope also included dredging activities (for a foundation trench, turning basin, main channel) with a total volume of 3.5 million cubic meters. CHEC was the contractor responsible for implementation.  Project implementation commenced in January 2007. The project was originally expected to reach completion within 30 months (July 2009). As of December 2009, construction of the main terminals and ancillary works were complete, but site cleaning activities had not yet been undertaken. The project was ultimately completed in February 2011. An official project completion ceremony was held on December 21, 2011.  However, the deferred payment (lending) arrangement between SPC and CHEC appears to have underperformed vis-à-vis the original expectations of CHEC. Sudan’s Ministry of Finance initially set up a special bank account into which SPC deposited its monthly operating income (worth approximately $200 million a year), and SPC was allowed to retain some but not all of these funds for its own purposes (such as construction and maintenance of port facilities and servicing its debts to CHEC). However, Sudan’s Ministry of Finance subsequently took away SPC’s ability to retain a portion of its monthly income around 2011 (when the Sudanese Government faced an acute foreign exchange shortage), which made it substantially more difficult for SPC to honor its monthly repayment obligations. CHEC later disclosed that SPC was in arrears but continued to make interest payments.
justification: Project focuses on port infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of container terminals and dredging works, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant for public housing complex in Tout Lui Faut
description: On January 13, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Suriname signed a $500,000 grant agreement for the construction of a public housing complex in Tout Lui Faut. The complex consisted of 200 low-income houses: 10 one-bedroom houses, 60 two-bedroom houses, and 130 three-bedroom houses. Suriname companies designed the complex, but Chinese companies were contracted for labor and construction.  On December 24, 2007, a contract for the implementation of the low-cost housing project was signed between the Ministry of Affairs and Housing of Suriname and China Shandong Foreign Economic and Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd.  Construction was delayed and did not begin until late 2008. On November 18, 2008, the groundbreaking ceremony was held.
staff_comments: The completion date is unknown; however, there is indication in sources that the project has been completed (See: Suriname Ministry of Social Affairs and Housing source), so project status has been coded as Completion.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant for public housing complex in Tout Lui Faut

# Description
On January 13, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Suriname signed a $500,000 grant agreement for the construction of a public housing complex in Tout Lui Faut. The complex consisted of 200 low-income houses: 10 one-bedroom houses, 60 two-bedroom houses, and 130 three-bedroom houses. Suriname companies designed the complex, but Chinese companies were contracted for labor and construction.  On December 24, 2007, a contract for the implementation of the low-cost housing project was signed between the Ministry of Affairs and Housing of Suriname and China Shandong Foreign Economic and Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd.  Construction was delayed and did not begin until late 2008. On November 18, 2008, the groundbreaking ceremony was held.
justification: Project is focused on public housing development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Public housing complex construction, low-income housing focus, social infrastructure purpose

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Auxiliary Office Building Construction for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Linked to Project ID#36682, #56155, #70315, #70449)
description: On June 12, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Suriname signed a grant agreement for the construction of an auxiliary office building for Suriname's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (BUZA). The value of the grant is unknown.  A design contract was signed in February 2007. Weihai International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation.   This project was completed and handed over to the authorities on February 11, 2016.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 时办公用房项目. The Dutch name of the project is 'Uitbreiding HQbuza.' One of the original sources is a broken link but it is recoverable via archive.org (wayback machine). The source is partially in Dutch and partially in English.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Auxiliary Office Building Construction for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Linked to Project ID#36682, #56155, #70315, #70449)

# Description
On June 12, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Suriname signed a grant agreement for the construction of an auxiliary office building for Suriname's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (BUZA). The value of the grant is unknown.  A design contract was signed in February 2007. Weihai International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation.   This project was completed and handed over to the authorities on February 11, 2016.
justification: Project involves construction of government office building without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Auxiliary office building construction for Ministry of Foreign Affairs, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China grants police materials to Suriname Customs
description: On June 29, 2006, a letter of exchange was signed by Chinese Ambassador Chen Jinghua and Minister of Finance Humphrey Hilton Bach for the Chinese government’s donation of police materials to Suriname Customs.   On May 17, 2007, a supply contract was signed.   On August 20, 2007, the police materials were handed over to the Suriname customs agency. The materials are intended to assist the Suriname customs agency in preventing illegal smuggling.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China grants police materials to Suriname Customs

# Description
On June 29, 2006, a letter of exchange was signed by Chinese Ambassador Chen Jinghua and Minister of Finance Humphrey Hilton Bach for the Chinese government’s donation of police materials to Suriname Customs.   On May 17, 2007, a supply contract was signed.   On August 20, 2007, the police materials were handed over to the Suriname customs agency. The materials are intended to assist the Suriname customs agency in preventing illegal smuggling.
justification: Project involves donation of police materials for customs operations, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of police materials to Suriname Customs for preventing illegal smuggling

title: Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant to control H5N1 (avian influenza)
description: According to a dataset of foreign-financed projects that Syria’s State Planning Commission (SPC) provided to UNDP Syria in May 2011, the Chinese Government provided a $500,000 grant to the Government of Syria’s Ministry of Agriculture and Agrarian Reform in January 2006 to combat and control H5N1 (avian influenza). This project was reportedly completed on December 31, 2006.
staff_comments: The Arabic project title is مكافحة انفلونزا الطيور
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant to control H5N1 (avian influenza)

# Description
According to a dataset of foreign-financed projects that Syria’s State Planning Commission (SPC) provided to UNDP Syria in May 2011, the Chinese Government provided a $500,000 grant to the Government of Syria’s Ministry of Agriculture and Agrarian Reform in January 2006 to combat and control H5N1 (avian influenza). This project was reportedly completed on December 31, 2006.
justification: Project focuses on disease control in agriculture without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Grant for H5N1 control, agricultural disease management focus
